stories.text:
Short and sharp, hope you all enjoy.

1/ Speak their language, not yours

If you’re trying to persuade people to do something, let them see themselves in your words. Let them trust you because the words are their own.

2/ Focus on benefits

Emphasise the benefit to the reader, not features.

Eugene Schwartz said, “Talk about what your product ‘does’, not ‘is’ - and demonstrate this.”

3/ Less is more

Give a clear, concise message, nothing more.

“Write to the chimpanzee brain - simply and directly.” - Eugene Schwartz

4/ Get their heads nodding

Ask questions in your copy that get your reader answering yes.

If they say yes once, they’re likely to say it again, and again, and again.

Once their heads are nodding, they’re hooked.

5/ Appeal to emotion.

What is your reader’s deepest desire? If you can capitalise on that, you’ll have a valuable customer.

The strongest, deepest emotions, not governed by rational thought, are:

- Greed - Guilt - Exclusivity - Fear - Anger - Salvation - Flattery

6/ Avoid ’weasel words’

Fill your audience with confidence, not doubt. Avoiding commanding words is a way to protect yourself, your reader will recognise that.

Replace may, hope, could, with will, can, do.

7/ You, You, We

Use the word ‘you’ at least twice as much as ‘we’.

If you speak about your prospect, you’ll naturally focus on their needs.

8/ Make it look good

Don’t waste well-written copy with poor aesthetic.

Make it appealing. - Short paragraphs - Variety in the text (italicising, bullet points, headings) - Images and vibrant colours

9/ Use numbers

Numbers drive credibility.

Confidence isn’t enough to win over skeptics; give them reliable data.

10/ Focus on one point

If you have something important to say, say it over and over again.

Richard Perry says, “Use a pile driver. Hit the point once. Then come back and hit it again. Then hit it a third time—a tremendous whack.”

11/ Relax.

Successful copy is personal and relaxed.

Don’t bother with formal language - just imagine you’re having a one-on-one conversation with your reader.

12/ Tell a story

Stories make you memorable.

13/ Snowball your reader

Every sentence should lead into the next.

And the next,

And the next.

Turn your copy into a snowball.

14/ Be funny

Nothing is more personal than humour.

You don’t need your reader in stitches - just let them know you’re a real person too.

-- You made it!

Hopefully it was helpful. I originally wrote an extended version for the newsletter of a new project I'm working on.

If you're interested in getting more marketing tips and tricks, check out upskillmarketing.org

Cheers, Connor.
